The abdomen is soft, depressible and painless and the lower limbs show no oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis.
On arrival, an electrocardiogram (ECG) was performed, showing ST-segment rectification in the inferior face of approximately 0.5 mm, and the patient was transferred to the monitored observation room.
Following the results of the first analysis, which showed elevated markers of myocardial damage, the on-call cardiologist was consulted.
On evaluation, a new ECG was performed with negative T waves in leads V5-V6 and in II, III and aVF.
A transthoracic echocardiogram was performed showing inferoapical and apical segmental contractility defects.
An attempt was made to perform a transesophageal echocardiogram to assess the mechanical aortic prosthesis, ruling out thrombosis.

Due to the analytical, echo and electrocardiographic findings, a diagnosis of high-risk non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome (NSTEACS) was made and early coronary angiography was requested, and the patient was transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) for continuous monitoring.
COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Initial ECG: sinus rhythm at 74 bpm, normal axis, isoelectric ST, flattened T waves in III and aVF but positive.
ECG on admission to ICU: sinus rhythm at 80 bpm, normal axis, development of negative T waves in II, III, aVF and from V3 to V6.
ST elevation 1 mm in III and rectification in aVF.

CBC: haemogram: leukocytes 7.7 thousands/μl, segmented (74%) 5.7 thousands/μl, lymphocytes (18.5%) 1.4 thousands/μl, red cells 4.23 million/μl, haemoglobin 13 g/dl, haematocrit 38.5%, MCV 91.1 fl, platelets 180 thousands/μl.
Coagulation: prothrombin time 12.9 seconds, prothrombin activity 80.0 %, aTTP 37.2 seconds, fibrinogen 638 mg/dl, INR 1.17 INR.

Biochemistry: glucose 87 mg/dl, urea 10 mg/dl, creatinine 0.51 mg/dl, estimated glomerular filtration rate (MDRD-4- IDMS) > 60 ml/min/1.73, sodium 136 mmol/l, potassium 3.5 mmol/l, chlorine 107 mmol/l, magnesium 1.96 mg/dl.
Peak myocardial damage markers: CPK 783 IU/l, TnIhs: 6953.3 ng/l.
Anti Xa levels: 1st determination: 0.71 IU/mL; 2nd determination: 0.8 IU/mL.

Transthoracic echocardiogram: non-dilated left ventricle without significant hypertrophy, subjectively preserved left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) with dyskinesia in the apex, distal inferior and distal septal, with normal diastolic pattern.
Mechanical aortic prosthesis with very discrete lavage jets and with parameters of GPAo 26 mmHg, GMAo 12 mmHg, LVOT LVOT/Ao ratio of 0.6 (no stenosis).
Right ventricle (RV) not dilated with normal systolic function, no tricuspid insufficiency (TI) to estimate pulmonary arterial systolic pressure (PSAP), no pericardial effusion.
Transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) (videos 1 and 2): no thrombosis of aortic mechanical prosthesis.
Left aortic valve without thrombus inside.
Non-dilated LV with no thrombus inside.
Left main coronary artery without significant stenosis.
Anterior descending artery of good calibre and development, with an image compatible with an embolus in the very distal section, in the apex and when the vessel is already of fine calibre.
Circumflex artery of good calibre and development, dominant, angiographically normal.
Right coronary artery of small calibre and development, non-dominant, without lesions.
CT scan of the aorta: the metallic aortic valve prosthesis and the post-surgical changes of the aortic root in the first 40 mm are observed.
Along the entire length of the ascending aorta there is a constant diameter of 30 mm.
Although optimal aortic lumen density has not been reached in the images obtained, there are no radiological findings suggestive of dissection along the aorta or its TSA.
No other radiologically significant findings were found with this imaging technique.
CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was admitted to the ICU for monitoring.

Prior to coronary angiography, the on-call gynaecology team was contacted and the patient was informed of the benefits/risks of the procedure and warned that due to the average radiation dose received per patient (less than 500 mGy), it was not advisable to legally terminate the pregnancy.

The haemodynamics department was then contacted to perform a preferential catheterisation, which identified an angiographic image suggestive of embolism in the very distal anterior descending coronary artery.
Subsequently, obstetric ultrasound was performed, which confirmed foetal viability.
On admission, aortic CT angiography was requested to detect aortic dissection and/or brachiocephalic and carotid trunk dissection, which was finally ruled out.
His stay in the ICU was uneventful.
The haematology department was consulted to adjust the anticoagulation dose which, prior to admission, was maintained at 12,000 IU (120 mg)/0.8 ml once a day.

The anticoagulant treatment was adjusted to 10,000 IU (100 mg)/1 ml every 12 hours and the patient was transferred to the cardiology ward, where antiXa levels were requested and showed borderline levels between prophylactic and therapeutic doses.

The most likely aetiology of NSTEACS was assumed to be coronary embolism in relation to the undercoagulated mechanical prosthesis, which in addition to releasing a small embolus into the coronary circulation, could possibly have released one into the cerebral circulation, causing the facial paresthesia and cervical pain.

After a multidisciplinary approach between the gynaecology, cardiology and haematology teams, it was decided that since the patient was still in the first trimester of pregnancy, treatment with LMWH should continue until week 13 (adjusted according to anti-Xa levels) and then reintroduce vitamin K antagonists (VKA) until delivery.
Her stay in the cardiology ward was uneventful and she was discharged after 5 days of hospitalisation.
DIAGNOSIS Acute myocardial infarction without septal and apical ST elevation in relation to embolism at the level of the very distal anterior descending coronary artery.
Undertherapeutic anticoagulation levels in a patient with a mechanical aortic prosthesis.
HISTORY, CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History
History 49-year-old woman, with no known allergies or toxic habits.
Lives at home with her parents, under guardianship, independent for basic activities of daily living (BADLL).
No cardiovascular risk factors or family history of heart disease.
Cardiological history of mitral prolapse with moderate mitral insufficiency under follow-up in cardiology consultations.
Other history of: cognitive deficit secondary to intrauterine infection, micrognathia and psoriasis without associated osteoarthritis.

Current illness Admission to cardiology, after detecting in outpatient clinic, where he went for review of his valvulopathy, ECG compatible with evolved AMI with anteroseptal Q wave, paucisymptomatic.

Anamnesis was difficult due to the patient's baseline condition; we spoke to her parents, who reported that she had presented at home in the previous days with episodes of epigastric pain and diffuse abdominal pain, which subsided with paracetamol 1g/8h, and for which they did not consult, without associated vegetative cortex.
They denied objective dyspnoea, chest pain or syncope.
There was no fever or associated infectious semiology at any level.
Likewise, for approximately two weeks, the patient has had clinical symptoms of instability with behavioural alterations, pending an appointment for neurological assessment.
Physical examination Blood pressure 120/75 mmHg, heart rate 98 bpm.
Conscious, oriented, normohydrated and perfused, eupneic at rest.
Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic heart sounds, known mitral II/VI systolic murmur.
Abdomen: soft, depressible, preserved peristalsis, painful on general palpation, no signs of peritoneal irritation, no murmurs.
Lower extremities: no oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis.
COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG on admission: sinus tachycardia at 127 bpm.
ST elevation V1-V4 Q in V1 V2.
ECG on discharge: sinus rhythm at 90 bpm, with negative T waves from V1 to V4.
Myocardial necrosis markers: ultrasensitive troponin T: 1050 -> 968.8 ng/l.
Blood tests: biochemistry: glucose 120 mg/dl, HbA1c 5.5%, urea 0.5 g/l, creatinine 1 mg/dl, glomerular filtration rate 90 ml/min.
Total cholesterol 112 mg/dl, LDL cholesterol 54 mg/dl, HDL cholesterol 45 mg/dl, triglycerides 83 mg/dl, sodium140 mEq/l, potassium 4 mEq/l.
Blood count: haemoglobin 14.2 g/dl, haematocrit 40%, leucocytes 6400/mm3, platelets 305000/mm3.
Myocardial perfusion scan at rest: non-viability.
Myocardial necrosis in the apex and anteroapical and anteroseptal segments (infarct area between 16% and 22% of the left ventricular area; LVEF 53%).
Coronary computed tomography (CT): occlusion of the middle anterior descending artery (AD) with permeable and filiform apical bed.
AMI in the anterior and apical septum (thinning and hypoperfusion in the apex and anterior septum).
Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) on admission: apical akinesia with preserved systolic function (LVEF 55%).

Mass visualised on the atrial side of the anterior leaflet in the mitral valve suggestive of vegetations, hypermobile, 1.17/0.5 cm in size, filiform with a wide base of implantation that conditions moderate-severe mitral insufficiency (A2-P3) with posterior eccentric jet and Coanda effect, without systolic inversion in the pulmonary veins.
No perforation of the leaflet or mitroaortic fibrosis was observed.
There is no mitral valve stenosis.
Echocardiogram at 6 weeks: left ventricle of normal size and thickness, with borderline systolic function (LVEF 50%).
Remarkable decrease in the size of the vegetation in the anterior mitral leaflet (almost complete disappearance).
Mitral valve prolapse of the anterior leaflet causing moderate regurgitation with eccentric jet (similar to studies prior to admission).
No perforation of the leaflet or involvement of the mitroaortic fibrosa was observed.
The rest of the patient had no significant valvular alterations.
Pulmonary arterial systolic pressure cannot be calculated due to the absence of tricuspid insufficiency.
PCR influenza and respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) 07/02/2020: negative.
Craniocerebral CT scan: hyperdense area compatible with haemorrhagic focus of 10 x 7 mm in left fronto-parietal lobe, which does not rule out the existence of underlying pathology.
Rest of the brain parenchyma without significant alterations.

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain: left occipital annular uptake that could be related to septic embolism, as well as left occipital temporal temporal corticojuxtacortical signal alteration suggesting acute-subacute ischaemic lesion and left frontal subacute haemorrhagic focus.
In context, the findings could all be related to septic embolism.
CLINICAL EVOLUTION Admitted with a diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction, paucisymptomatic.

In the first hours of hospitalisation he presented febrile peaks of up to 38oC, with no associated infectious semiology, so blood and urine cultures were requested, PCR for respiratory viruses and empirical antibiotic therapy was started, which was modified after growth of S.
anginosus in the first 24 hours in both blood cultures, to intravenous penicillin G sodium and intravenous gentamicin.
TTE showed apical akinesia with preserved LVEF and an image suggestive of vegetation in the anterior mitral leaflet (atrial side) of 11 mm, which led to moderate regurgitation with eccentric jet.
Of note, it was impossible to perform a transesophageal echocardiogram due to the patient's facial anatomy.

On the one hand, in the case of a recently diagnosed advanced acute myocardial infarction, a viability study was performed with myocardial perfusion scintigraphy at rest, showing an absence of viability in the segments compatible with the LAD territory.
A coronary CT scan was also performed, confirming occlusion in the mid LAD with a permeable and filiform apical bed.
It was decided not to revascularise due to the absence of clinical benefit, and the patient remained stable without new episodes of chest pain.
Residual LV systolic function was preserved with apical akinesia at discharge.

On the other hand, with the diagnosis of subacute endocarditis in native mitral valve, together with the initial clinical manifestations of instability and behavioural alteration, as well as diffuse abdominal pain, an extension study was performed with: Cranioencephalic CT and cerebral MRI which confirmed the existence of images suggestive of septic embolisms and abdominal CT where no significant alterations were found.
Both ruled out the presence of abscesses.
A gynaecological examination was also performed, which ruled out abscess or complications at this level.

Subsequent clinical and haemodynamic evolution was favourable, with negative blood cultures at 72 hours, presenting as a complication urinary tract infection by E coli and Enterococcus faecium 2 weeks after starting antibiotherapy, for which treatment was escalated, replacing penicillin with ceftriaxone, completing 6 weeks of antibiotic treatment, with no other complications.

After completing the 6 weeks, a new control TTE was repeated, where the vegetation practically disappeared, with prolapse of the anterior mitral leaflet leading to moderate residual mitral insufficiency similar to previous studies and preserved left ventricular systolic function.
Given the absence of progression of mitral regurgitation (MR) and the disappearance of valvular vegetations in a frail patient (FRAIL 5; CFS 7), conservative treatment was chosen.

Finally, after completion of the physiotherapy programme by the rehabilitation service, with progressive recovery of motor function, she was discharged home with outpatient follow-up, with no episodes of decompensation to date and in NYHA functional class I at the last review.
DIAGNOSIS Subacute endocarditis on native mitral valve (anterior leaflet) due to Streptococcus anginosus (viridans) resolved with prolonged antibiotic therapy and complicated with septic embolism:
Acute embolic apical myocardial infarction with occlusion in middle LAD not revascularised due to lack of viability.
Left occipital and left frontotemporal ischaemic cerebrovascular accident (CVA) (with subsequent haemorrhagic transformation) due to septic embolisms.
Borderline residual LV systolic function (LVEF 50%) with apical akinesia.
Urinary tract infections due to E coli and Enterococcus faecium.
HISTORY, CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History
History 49-year-old male patient with the following personal history: No known adverse drug reactions.

Cardiovascular risk factors: arterial hypertension of 13 years of evolution, initially untreated and which, in recent years, has had treatment with irregular adherence to it; dyslipidaemia of 8 years of evolution, in treatment with oral lipid-lowering drugs, but also with irregular adherence to it.
Toxic habits: active smoker of more than 15 cigarettes a day (IPA of 35 packs/year), alcoholism with a regular consumption of around 1 litre of beer a day since adolescence, occasional cocaine user.
Cardiological history: Chronic coronary syndrome, with debut in 2012 in the form of acute myocardial infarction without ST-segment elevation (NSTEMI).
During this admission, monovalvular coronary artery disease of the proximal anterior descending artery was detected, which was revascularised with the implantation of 1 drug-eluting stent.
Left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) was preserved at discharge.

New admission in 2017 for NSTEMI, caused by thrombosis at the level of the proximal ostial circumflex artery without total obstruction and treated with abciximab perfusion initially and subsequently with balloon PCI.
Abandoned follow-up in cardiology outpatient clinic.

Usual treatment: acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) 100 mg (1 tablet every 24 h), omeprazole 20 mg (1 tablet every 24 h), telmisartan 40 mg (1 tablet every 24 h), lorazepam 1 mg (1 tablet every 12 h), bisoprolol 2.5 mg (1 tablet every 24 h), atorvastatin 80 mg (1 tablet every 24 h), fenofibrate 145 mg (1 tablet every 24 h).
Present illness The patient, with the history described above, presents with chest pain at home, unrelated to exertion.

He describes the pain as central thoracic, oppressive, radiating to the neck and left upper limb, similar to the two previous heart attacks and accompanied by vegetative symptoms in the form of profuse sweating and nausea.
Initially, he decided to take one tablet of lorazepam and, as his symptoms worsened, he decided to take two tablets of sublingual caffeine, which he vomited immediately.
The family then called the emergency services.

On arrival of the emergency team, the patient was symptomatic, with chest pain and significant impairment of the general condition, conscious, oriented and cooperative, with the following physical examination: Vitals: systolic blood pressure of 95/54 mmHg; heart rate of around 100 bpm, saturating at 96% without oxygen supply.
Skin pallor, acral coldness, weak peripheral pulses.
Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic tones, tachycardic, no audible murmurs.
Pulmonary auscultation: bilateral vesicular murmur preserved, with crackles in the bases.

An electrocardiogram (ECG) was then performed, showing ST segment elevation (images 1 and 2), so it was decided to administer a loading dose of ASA (300 mg), ticagrelor (180 mg), and emergency cardiology was contacted pre-hospital for transfer to our hospital.
COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Emergency ECG: sinus rhythm at 90 bpm, normal PR, ST segment elevation in DII, DIII, AVF (up to 7 mm) and in V4-6, with specular decrease in V1-2, aVL.
Initial coronary angiography (video 1): Left main coronary artery: No stenosis.

Recurrence of very late thrombosis of the stent implanted in the ostial anterior descending artery, a phenomenon that in this case affects the distal left main coronary artery (both anterior descending and circumflex), but maintaining TIMI 3 epicardial flow in both branches.
Anterior descending: permeable ostial-proximal ostial stent, not restenotic, with presence of ostial thrombus.
Rest of the vessel without de novo lesions.
Occlusion by embolisation of the anterior descending artery at the terminal (apical) level.
Circumflex: co-dominant, without lesions, with presence of ostial-proximal thrombus, as previously detailed.
Occlusion by embolus of the distal posterior descending artery of the circumflex.
Right coronary artery: codominant, without lesions.
Post-catheterisation ECG on admission to the coronary unit (image 3): sinus rhythm with narrow QRS, normalisation of the ST segment, Q wave of 1 mm in DII, DIII, aVF, V5-6.
Admission blood tests: haemogram: red series with Hb 15.7 g/dl and haematocrit 45.8%.
White series with leukocytosis of 17,760 cells/mm3 and neutrophilia of 15,590 cells/mm3.
Renal function: creatinine 1.04 mg/dl and urea 33 mg/dl.
GSV: pH 7.25; pCO2 40.4 mmHg; lactic acid 7.4 mmol/l; HCO3- 17.7 mmol/l.
Lipid profile: total cholesterol 103 mg/dl; triglycerides 92 mg/dl; HDL cholesterol 60 mg/dl; LDL cholesterol 25 mg/dl.
Urinalysis with toxins: positive for cocaine and benzodiazepines.
Echocardiography in the ED: left ventricle of globular appearance, with preserved LVEF, no segmental contractility disorders can be seen due to poor endocardial visualisation.
Right ventricle of normal size and preserved systolic function.
Vena cava of normal size and with adequate inspiratory collapse.
Control coronary angiography at 7 days: resolution of the stent thrombosis generated in the ostial anterior descending artery, described in the previous angiography, was confirmed.

Doppler ultrasound of the left groin: hypoechogenic image is seen in the perivascular soft tissues, adjacent to the superficial femoral artery, with no flow inside, compatible with changes secondary to puncture, probably haematic infiltration.
No significant post-puncture haematoma is evident.
All the vessels studied appear permeable and with normal flow morphology.
There were no images suggesting additional complications: arteriovenous fistula or pseudoaneurysm.
ECG at hospital discharge: sinus rhythm at 65 bpm.
Negative T waves in II, III, aVF and V4-6.

Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) at discharge: non-dilated left ventricle, with slight concentric hypertrophy of walls (13 mm of septum and 13 mm of posterior wall), with preserved left ventricular systolic function (57%), without segmental contractility disorders.
Right ventricle not dilated and normofunctioning.
Inferior vena cava not dilated with adequate inspiratory collapse.
The Doppler study showed normal anterograde valvular flows, with no significant valvular insufficiencies.
Blood tests at discharge: Normal haemogram of the 3 series.
Biochemistry: glycaemia, renal function and ions normal.
Markers of myocardial damage: CPK 87 U/l and TnT 5 ng/l.
GSV: pH 7.37; pCO2 50.5 mmHg; HCO3 28.6 mmol/l; lactic 2.1 mmol/l.

CLINICAL EVOLUTION On arrival at the hospital emergency department, the patient was found to be in a very poor general state, hypotensive and with a low level of consciousness, which made it necessary to initiate aminergic support (noradrenaline) with a view to performing primary angioplasty in which thrombosis was observed in the area of the ostium of the anterior descending trunk and trunk-circumflex.
As in the NSTEACS of 2017, initial pharmacological management was chosen in order to reduce the thrombotic burden prior to any interventional procedure.
Thus, an intracoronary bolus of abciximab was administered and intravenous perfusion was left in place.

After starting this treatment, haemodynamic improvement and recovery of the level of consciousness was observed, and the patient was transferred to the coronary unit for continued monitoring and follow-up.

The case was presented at a medical-surgical session and it was decided to repeat the coronary angiography after 7 days, depending on the results of the coronary angiography, medical treatment, percutaneous revascularisation or surgery could be considered depending on the findings.

During his stay, initially in the coronary unit and subsequently in the cardiology ward, the patient evolved favourably in clinical and haemodynamic terms, with no congestive signs, no arrhythmic events, no recurrence of chest pain and with preserved LVEF without complications in the control TTE.

On re-history, the patient reported that in the previous weeks he had increased his alcohol and tobacco consumption, and that he had used cocaine again on several occasions, the last dose the day before the event.
A repeat coronary angiography was performed 7 days later, in this case via the femoral artery, and resolution of the thrombus was observed.

In view of this situation, it was decided not to perform any more invasive procedures on this patient and, after an adequate evolution on the hospital ward, it was decided to discharge the patient with recommendations, leaving him on a double anti-aggregation treatment with ASA and ticagrelor.

Prior to discharge, the patient presented a painful tumour in the inguinal region, coinciding with the puncture site for coronary angiography via the femoral artery, which made it necessary to perform a Doppler ultrasound to rule out complications of the procedure.
After performing the ultrasound and ruling out these complications, the patient was discharged from the hospital.
Emphasis was placed on the importance of abandoning the consumption of toxic substances and the importance of therapeutic compliance.
He was transferred to the cardiac rehabilitation unit on discharge, where these recommendations were insisted on, as well as diet and physical exercise.
After follow-up, he was discharged with subsequent review in outpatient cardiology consultations.
At the present time, and more than 1 year after the acute event, the patient has completely abandoned the consumption of toxic substances and has not presented any further coronary events.
Given his history, it was also decided to prolong the double antiplatelet therapy, and the patient is currently on ticagrelor 60 mg every 12 hours.

Late stent thrombosis in ostial anterior descending artery affecting the left common trunk and the ostium of the circumflex artery with TIMI 3 flow but with distal embolisation with occlusion of distal anterior descending and distal posterior descending arteries.
Pharmacological treatment with intracoronary abciximab and later triple antiplatelet therapy with intravenous abciximab and ASA + ticagrelor orally.
Global preserved LVEF with no mechanical complications or valvular heart disease.
Cocaine use as a precipitating factor.
HISTORY, CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History
History 26-year-old male, high-intensity sportsman, firefighter by profession.
No family history of heart disease or sudden death (SD) at an early age.
No consumption of other toxic substances.
No medical illnesses or surgical interventions of interest.

Current illness Patient attended the emergency department in March 2020 for an episode of dizziness associated with loss of vision and a fall to the floor while at rest, while making a sudden neck twisting movement, without knowing whether she lost consciousness.
Immediate recovery with no post-critical period, no sphincter relaxation or tonic-clonic movements.
She reported that this was the first time this symptomatology had occurred, denying previous syncopal episodes or palpitations.
Physical examination General state of health.
Blood pressure (BP) 125/65 mmHg, heart rate (HR) 55 bpm.
Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic, at a good frequency.
Abdomen: soft, non-painful, no masses or megaliths.
Lower limbs: no oedema or signs of venous insufficiency or deep vein thrombosis.
Distal pulses present and symmetrical  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS

COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: sinus bradycardia at 55 bpm, normal axis, short PR with marked pre-excitation (positive delta wave in I, inferior face and from V1-V6, negative in avL), wide QRS due to initial filling with RsR' morphology in V1 with marked repolarisation alterations with ST underleveling and negative T waves in II, III, aVF and V1-V6.
CBC: haemoglobin 14.6 g/dl, leucocytes 7200/microl (67% PMN), platelets 365,000/microl.
Biochemistry: creatinine 0.67 mg/dl, urea 28 mg/dl, ions normal.
Hepatobiliary profile and thyroid hormones normal.

Echocardiogram (videos 1 and 2): left ventricle not dilated, without ventricular hypertrophy but showing marked hypertrabeculation especially at the apical, lower apical, middle and lateral apical levels, with numerous intraventricular recesses which are checked by colour Doppler for communication with the ventricular cavity.
LVEF at the limit of normality (LVEFbp 55%).
Left ventricular (LV) diastolic function: normal transmitral pattern with E/A ratio 1.4 and TDE 296 ms.
Normal filling pressures (average E/E ́ 8, lateral E ́ 16 cm/s, medial E ́ 8.5 cm/s, LA < 34 ml/m2, IT < 2.8 m/s).
Right ventricle of normal size with normal systolic function (TAPSE 23 mm).
Inferior vena cava of adequate calibre and respiratory dynamics.
The test was stopped when the target heart rate (HR) was reached.
No chest pain or dyspnoea during exercise.
No dynamic changes suggestive of ischaemia.

During the entire tracing, there was overt pre-excitation with secondary repolarisation alterations, which disappeared when the heart rate reached 170 bpm and the repolarisation alterations disappeared.
Subsequently, during recovery, the patient remained without pre-excitation and without repolarisation alterations due to probable exhaustion of the accessory pathway.
There were no arrhythmic events of interest.
Conclusions: clinically and electrically negative for ischaemia.
Holter: RS study with HR between 24-43-95 bpm.
Maximum pause of 3.7 seconds, intermittent pre-excitation.
Cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR): left ventricle (LV) slightly dilated with marked trabeculation of the myocardium, on all sides except the septum and basal segments that show less trabeculae.
The ratio of non-compacted myocardium to compacted myocardium (NCM/CM) is greater than 2.3 with a maximum value of 4.3 in several segments.
Global and segmental mobility are preserved.
The EF measured with the Simpson method is 62%.
VTDVI of 243 ml, indexed by body surface area of 124 ml/m2, VTSVI of 91.6 ml, indexed by body surface area of 47 ml/m2.
There were deep crypts located at the inferior junction of both ventricles, another in the middle anteroseptal segment and the third at the level of the apical inferior segment.
The right ventricle is neither dilated nor hypertrophic, with marked hypertrabeculation.
The EF measured with the Simpson method is 66%.
Both atria are of normal size.
The first-pass perfusion sequence shows no perfusion defect at rest.
Late enhancement/viability sequence does not show gadolinium retention suggesting necrosis and/or fibrosis.
Conclusion: non-compaction cardiomyopathy with involvement of both ventricles.

ECG after ablation: sinus tachycardia at 105 bpm, normal axis, PR 146 ms, narrow QRS, non-pathological q wave in inferior face, ST rectification in inferior face and V5-V6 with negative T in inferior face, normal QTc.

CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was assessed in the emergency department by the cardiology service in the event of a syncopal episode, and an electrocardiogram was performed in sinus rhythm with short PR and a marked positive delta wave in inferior aspect and V1-V6 and negative in aVL, thus giving the impression of a left lateral accessory pathway.

Laboratory tests and chest X-ray were performed, compatible with normality, as well as echocardiography showing a non-dilated left ventricle but with marked hypertrabeculation at the apical, apical lateral and lower middle and apical levels, with numerous recesses communicating with the ventricular cavity, with preserved LVEF, right ventricle of normal morphology and function and no significant valvulopathies (videos 1 and 2).

Given the suspicion of non-compaction cardiomyopathy with left lateral accessory pathway, studies were completed with genetic study and screening of first-degree relatives and CMR (images 2, 3 and 4) which confirmed the presence of non-compaction cardiomyopathy with biventricular involvement, more marked in the left ventricle, which was slightly dilated and affected in all segments except the septum and basal segments, with a maximum ratio between non-compacted and compacted myocardium of 4.3.
There are deep crypts located at the inferior junction of both ventricles, another in the mid anteroseptal segment and the third at the level of the apical inferior segment.
The rest of the study was compatible with normality, with preserved biventricular systolic function and no fibrosis in the late enhancement sequence.

The patient was referred to the arrhythmia and electrophysiology unit and underwent ergometry, reaching 24 METs, without arrhythmic events during the test and with marked pre-excitation during the start of the test, which disappeared when 170 bpm was reached, and remained without pre-excitation during recovery.
A 24-hour Holter monitor was also performed, which showed the presence of intermittent pre-excitation but no arrhythmic events of interest.

Based on the above, it was decided to perform an electrophysiological study (EPS) in May 2020, and programmed stimulation was performed with the finding of concentric decremental anterograde conduction at baseline (and, therefore, through the specific conduction system) which became eccentric and with an earlier ventriculogram at the left lateral level after infusion of isoproterenol (via the accessory pathway).

Similarly, atrioventricular dissociation is observed at 600 ms in programmed retrograde pacing from the right ventricular apex, which changes to concentric decremental retrograde conduction after isoproterenol infusion.
The anterograde refractory period of the pathway is measured and is 240 ms after isoproterenol infusion.
No tachycardias are induced after baseline programmed atrial and ventricular pacing and after isoproterenol.

Mitral annulus mapping was performed by retroaortic access, with radiofrequency ablation at the left anterolateral level, and ablation was effective with disappearance of pre-excitation in 2.5 seconds.

After ablation, the patient continued subsequent follow-up in the arrhythmia and electrophysiology unit, remaining asymptomatic in NYHA functional class I and without events in serial Holter monitoring, in sinus rhythm without pre-excitation in the baseline ECG although maintaining marked alterations in ventricular repolarisation.
In October 2020, the results of the genetic study were obtained, identifying a previously undescribed variant in the ACTC1 gene (p.

Pro260Leu), which could be associated with the patient's phenotype (non-compaction cardiomyopathy), although more information is needed to confirm this, and screening of first-degree relatives has yet to be completed.
DIAGNOSIS Non-compaction cardiomyopathy with biventricular involvement and preserved systolic function.
Slight dilatation of the left ventricle.
Left anterolateral accessory pathway with intermittent pre-excitation.
Successful ablation of the pathway by radiofrequency.
Variant of uncertain significance in the ACTC1 gene (p.
HISTORY, CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History
Cardiovascular risk factors: hypertension with good ambulatory control.
Non-insulin-dependent type 2 diabetes mellitus with good outpatient control.
Mixed dyslipidaemia with good outpatient control.
Cardiological history: paroxysmal atrial fibrillation with two electrical cardioversions (2016 and 2018).
Other medical and surgical history: depressive disorder, essential thrombocythemia, severe neurotrophic corneal ulcer operated on.

Usual treatment: fluoxetine 20 mg (1 tablet every day, started one month ago), lorazepam 1 mg (every day), acenocoumarol 1 mg (1 tablet every day and adjust according to controls), amiodarone 200 mg (1 tablet every other day), chlorthalidone 50 mg (1 tablet every day), irbesartan 300 mg (1 tablet every day), felodipine 5 mg (1 tablet every day), atorvastatin 20 mg (1 tablet every day), glimepiride 20 mg (1 tablet daily), linagliptin 5 mg (1 tablet daily), doxycycline 200 mg (1 capsule daily) and 1 tablet 100 mg (daily), moxifloxacin ophthalmic, paracetamol/tramadol 75/650 mg (1 tablet every 12 hours), famotidine 20 mg (1 tablet daily), pantoprazole 20 mg (1 tablet daily), anagrelide 0.5 mg (2 tablets every 7 days).

Present illness The patient is an 80-year-old woman who comes to the point of continuous care (PAC) for symptoms of loss of consciousness the day before the consultation and on three occasions during the same, lasting approximately 30 seconds and complete spontaneous recovery.
She also had a feeling of dizziness of the unsteadiness type and previous tinnitus, with no associated vegetative cortex.
No infectious clinical manifestations due to equipment.

During her stay in the PAC, she presented a new episode witnessed by the doctor, who defibrillated on evidence of pulseless ventricular fibrillation (PSVF) on the electrocardiogram - which we do not have - and performed cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) manoeuvres for less than 5 minutes.
After recovery of sinus rhythm, the patient was referred to the hospital emergency department.

Once there, the critical box monitor showed a torsade de Pointes (TdP) rhythm, initiated by the phenomenon of R over T, self-limited for seconds, with presyncopal symptoms, so isoproterenol and magnesium sulphate perfusion was started.

It was decided not to implant a temporary pacemaker due to the non-relapse of the arrhythmia with isoproterenol perfusion (the patient remained in sinus rhythm at 95 bpm) and was admitted to the coronary care unit (CCU) for monitoring and correction of triggering factors.
Physical examination Blood pressure (BP) 125/84 mmHg, heart rate (HR) 95 bpm, oxygen saturation 98% with FiO2 21%.
Cardiopulmonary auscultation: regular, no audible murmurs.
Vesicular murmur preserved, without added noises.
Abdomen: soft and depressible, no palpable masses or organomegaly, not painful on palpation.
No signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).
Language correct in form and content.
Strength and sensitivity of limbs preserved and symmetrical (5/5).

COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiograms (ECG): Health Centre: sinus rhythm at 80 bpm, PR 160 ms, QRS 120 ms with morphology of complete right bundle branch block (CRBBB) and electrical axis at -60o, asymmetrical negative T waves in V3-V6, flattened T waves in I, II, III and aVL.
In the critical care unit: polymorphic ventricular tachycardia of the TdP type.
On discharge from the cardiology ward: sinus rhythm at 65 bpm, PR 160 ms, QRS 160 ms with BCRDHH morphology and electrical axis at -60o, asymmetrical negative T waves in V1 and III.
Blood tests: haemoglobin 10.9 g/dl, MCV 81.6 fl, MCH 25.3 pg, MCHC 31 g/dl, leukocytes 10 10*9/l, neutrophils 8 10*9/l, lymphocytes 1 10*9/l, platelets 190 10*9/l.

Biochemistry: glucose 137 mg/dl, sodium 136 mEq/l, potassium 2.9 mEq/l, magnesium 1.6 mg/dl, calcium corrected to albumin 8.1 mg/dl, chlorine 94 mEq/l total bilirubin 3.99 mg/dl, direct bilirubin 2.07 mg/dl, indirect bilirubin 1.92 mg/dl, alanine aminotransferase GPT 34 U/l, urea 91 mg/dl, creatinine 1.08 mg/dl, estimated glomerular filtration rate (GFR) CKDEPI 48.6 ml/min/1.73 m2, C-reactive protein 7.1 mg/dl, ferritin 109 ng/dl, iron 47 g/dl, transferrin saturation index 15.2%, uric acid 10.2 mg/dl, protein 6.6 g/dl, TSH 2.3 mIU/l.
Arterial blood gases: pH 7.52 pCO2 40 mmHg, pO2 75 mmHg, HCO3a 32.7 mmol/l, O2SAT 95.7%, lactate 2.3 mmol/l.
Transthoracic echocardiogram: concentric left ventricular hypertrophy.
Increased left ventricular volumes with global hypokinesia, more severe in lower segments, and severe depression of global systolic function (LVEF 32%).
Mitral filling pattern suggestive of increased end-diastolic pressure.
Right ventricle with normal diameters and mild depression of global systolic function, mild tricuspid insufficiency (TI) with GP 31 mmHg.
Estimated systolic pulmonary artery pressure (SPAP) 35 mmHg.
Chest X-ray: very poorly inspired study.
Increased bilateral perihilar alveolar raster, which could correspond to discrete oedema.
There were no images suggestive of pulmonary consolidation.
Degenerative changes in the dorsal spine.
Coronary angiography: epicardial coronary arteries without lesions.

CLINICAL EVOLUTION During her stay in the OCU, the patient remained asymptomatic and electrocardiograms showed prolonged QT interval (QTc 639 ms), of probable iatrogenic acquired aetiology, as she was taking up to 3 drugs with known risk of TdP (moxifloxacin, anagrelide, amiodarone) and 4 that could be arrhythmogenic in specific conditions (fluoxetine, pantoprazole, famotidine and tramadol).
In addition, blood tests showed mild hypokalaemia, hypomagnesaemia and hypocalcaemia, electrolyte disorders that predispose to prolongation of the QT interval.
For all these reasons, it was decided to discontinue the predisposing medication and to supplement magnesium, calcium and potassium to correct their plasma levels.

After 48 hours of monitoring without new episodes and correction of the QTc to 540 ms, it was decided to transfer him to the cardiology ward to complete treatment and study (HF with severe ventricular dysfunction with moderate mitral insufficiency (MI) on regular echocardiography).
During her stay in the cardiology ward, coronary angiography was performed to complete the study of dilated cardiomyopathy without any pathological findings.

The patient progressed favourably and due to clinical and haemodynamic stability and correction of the electrocardiographic alteration, after 19 days in hospital it was decided to discharge her home with subsequent monitoring and follow-up by the heart failure unit.

Pharmacological treatment was started for HF with reduced LVEF (sacubitril/valsartan 24/26 mg [1 tablet every 12 h], eplerenone 25 mg [1 tablet every 24 h], nebivolol 2.5 mg [0.5 tablet every 24 h], dapagliflozin 10 mg [1 tablet every 24 h], furosemide 40 mg [1 tablet every 24 h]) together with magnesium 53 mg [2 tablets every 12 h] and edoxaban 30 mg [1 tablet every 24 h].
Similarly, it was decided to discontinue drugs precipitating QT interval prolongation (fluoxetine, moxifloxacin, amiodarone, pantoprazole and famotidine).

In the cardiology outpatient follow-up, one month after discharge home, and after optimal medical treatment of HF, the patient showed clinical stability with no recurrence of HF, partial recovery of LVEF (current LVEF 40%) and QT interval within normal limits.
Therefore, the patient is labelled as non-ischaemic dilated cardiomyopathy with a tachycardiomyopathy component and treatment is maintained at the appropriate doses.

DIAGNOSIS Iatrogenic acquired prolonged QT interval (pharmacological and hydroelectrolytic) with arrhythmic events in the form of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (torsade de Pointes) and recovered cardiorespiratory arrest.
Heart failure with reduced LVEF in the context of non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy with some component of tachycardiomyopathy.
HISTORY, CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History
No arterial hypertension, no diabetes mellitus, no dyslipidaemia.
No known heart disease or bronchopathy.
Advanced chronic kidney disease on haemodialysis programme, secondary to autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease.
Renal transplant in May 2018 with acute rejection on the 10th day with good subsequent response.
Proximal deep vein thrombosis at the level of superficial femoral, popliteal vein and deep and twin branches of left lower limb in November 2018 in current treatment with acenocoumarol.
Pyelonephritis of the renal graft in March 2019 with good response to antibiotic treatment.
Current treatment: prednisone 20 mg/24 hours, tacrolimus 4 mg/24 hours, omeprazole 20 mg/24 hours, enoxaparin 60 mg/24 hours and furosemide 40 mg/24 hours.

Present illness He was admitted from the nephrology department for clinical manifestations of fever, predominantly nocturnal, up to 38.3oC, of 2 weeks of evolution, together with exertional dyspnoea NYHA III, orthopnoea, oedematisation of the lower limbs and cough with whitish expectoration.

He had been admitted 2 months previously for the same reason with partial improvement and without identification of the aetiology, but the symptoms recurred after discontinuation of antibiotic therapy.
No micturition symptoms, no alterations in bowel habits.
On previous admission, a study was performed for a similar clinical picture and fever of unknown origin.
Chest CT scan on admission showed mild pericardial effusion and a micronodular interstitial pattern with well-defined nodules, bilaterally and symmetrically distributed.

In this context, blood cultures, urine cultures and serology were negative and there was no PCR detection of cytomegalovirus, Pneumocystis jirovecii (in bronchoalveolar lavage) and respiratory viruses.
Negative smear microscopy, PCR for tuberculosis in bronchoalveolar lavage and bronchoaspirate and negative mycobacterial culture.
Galactomannan for aspergillus in bronchoalveolar lavage negative.
Negative PCR for Leishmania in bone marrow.

Given the lack of detection of an aetiological agent during admission and the improvement with antibiotic treatment, it was decided to discharge the patient on a course of ciprofloxacin and follow-up in consultations.
Blood pressure 136/80 mmHg, heart rate 100 bpm, oxygen saturation 96% (FiO2 0.21).
Central venous pressure: absence of jugular ingurgitation.
Cardiac and respiratory auscultation: rhythmic tones without audible murmurs.
Vesicular murmur with no added sounds.
Abdomen: soft, depressible, not painful on palpation.
Lower limbs: left lower limb with signs of deep venous thrombosis (already known) with increased diameter compared to the right.
Right lower limb with oedema in the distal third with fovea.
COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Blood tests on admission: haemoglobin 11.6 g/dl, MCV 77 fl, MCH 23.4 pg, leukocytes 3,350/μl, neutrophils 2,540/μl, lymphocytes 470/μl and platelets 99,000/μ.
Biochemistry: glucose 86 mg/dl, urea 119 mg/dl, creatinine 3.34 mg/dl, sodium 140 mEq/l, potassium 3.7 mEq/l, chlorine 97 mEq/l, magnesium 1.4 mg/dl.

AST 11 U/l, ALT 10 U/l, GGT 104 U/l, alkaline phosphatase 114 U/l, LDH 209 U/l, protein 5.5 g/dl, albumin 2.90 g/dl, iron 34 μg/dl, ferritin 293 μg/ml, transferrin 145 mg/dl, transferrin saturation index 18.46%.
Urine system: glucose, protein, bilirubin, haemoglobin, leukocyte esterase and nitrites negative.
Electrocardiogram: sinus rhythm at 100 bpm, normal PR, narrow QRS with normal axis, no low voltages.
Chest CT: bilateral and diffuse micronodular lung pattern.
Blood cultures, urine culture and sputum culture: negative.
Echocardiogram on admission: left atrium of normal size: area 15 cm2 and volume 29 ml (15 ml/m2).
Left ventricle of normal size, mild parietal hypertrophy, preserved global systolic function (IVS 14mm, Dd 56 mm, Ds 31 mm, LVEF by Teicholtz 76%).
Biphasic filling pattern with E/A ratio at 1.5, E/E' at 6.4 (lateral).
Right ventricle with good function (TAPSE of 22 mm, lateral S' peak at 18 cm/sec).
Minimal TR allowing estimation of normal PSAP.
Normal right atrium with area 15 cm2 and volume 33 ml (16 ml/m2).
Inferior vena cava not dilated with adequate inspiratory collapse.
Severe circumferential pericardial effusion with an M-mode measurement in the parasternal long axis: 19 + 18 mm.
Respiratory variation of mitral filling flow less than 25%.
Conclusion: severe pericardial effusion, without haemodynamic repercussion by echocardiography.
Chest X-ray after pericardiocentesis: normal cardiothoracic index, not suggestive of pericardial effusion.
Increased perihilar vascular network, without condensation or occupation of costophrenic sinuses.
Pericardial fluid analysis: Cells: erythrocytes 265,200/μl and leukocytes 1,432/μl (10% neutrophils and 90% monocytes).
Glucose 77 mg/dl (VN 70-110 mg/dl), protein 3.9 g/dl, amylase 33 U/l (VN 0-100 U/l), LDH 1,085 U/l.
Pathology of pericardial fluid: pericardial fluid cytology negative for malignancy.
Cytological smear very haematic with abundant mixed lymphocytic and polymorphonuclear inflammatory cellularity.
With fewer histiocytes; no giant cells, no granulomas, no evidence of BAAR with Zhiel technique.
Microbiology: Sputum culture and antibiogram: negative.
Pericardial fluid culture and antibiogram: negative.
PCR of extrapulmonary tuberculosis in pericardial fluid: PCR of the tuberculous complex positive.
Mycobacterium tuberculosis mutations in pericardial fluid: no mutations in RPO-B gene associated with rifampicin resistance were detected.
Mycobacterial culture in pericardial fluid: positive for Mycobacterium tuberculosis (result obtained after discharge).
Blood tests prior to discharge: haemoglobin 12.4 g/dl, MCV 81.3 fl, MCH 24.9 pg, leukocytes 2,910/μl, neutrophils 1990/μl, lymphocytes 540/μl and platelets 125,000/μl.
Biochemistry: glucose 73 mg/dl, urea 96 mg/dl, creatinine 3.39 mg/dl, sodium 142 mEq/l, potassium 4.5 mEq/l, chlorine 109 mEq/l, magnesium 1.5 mg/dl.

AST 14 U/l, ALT 15 U/l, GGT 96 U/l, alkaline phosphatase 128 U/l, LDH 209 U/l, protein 5.4 g/dl, albumin 2.90 g/dl, iron 61 μg/dl, ferritin 271.9 μg/ml, transferrin 142 mg/dl, transferrin saturation index 33.82%.
CLINICAL EVOLUTION During admission, he had a good evolution with no fever peaks and improvement of dyspnoea after diuretic and antibiotic treatment.
Blood cultures, urine culture, sputum culture and Mantoux were negative.
The transthoracic echocardiogram on admission showed preserved biventricular function with severe circumferential pericardial effusion without signs of haemodynamic compromise.

As this was a patient with immunosuppressive treatment, fever of unknown origin and these findings in the chest CT scan, tuberculosis was suspected despite Mantoux and negative tests from the previous admission, so treatment was extended for coverage.
In addition, it was decided to perform diagnostic pericardiocentesis, previously explaining the risks to the patient due to the presence of liver cysts associated with polycystic kidney disease.
It was performed without complications, obtaining 800 ml of serohaematic content and sending the extracted fluid for biochemical and microbiological analysis.
Biochemical analysis of the pericardial fluid was compatible with exudate.
Cytology showed a very haematic content with abundant mixed lymphocytic and polymorphonuclear inflammatory cellularity.

In the microbiological analysis, the culture of the first days was negative, but with positive PCR for tuberculous complex without the presence of mutations in the RPO-B gene associated with resistance to rifampicin.
Thus, the diagnosis of tuberculosis was confirmed despite the other negative tests and the corresponding treatment was completed.

The patient remained afebrile and improved in analytical and radiographic controls, so it was decided to discharge him from hospital with his immunosuppressive treatment (tacrolimus and prednisone) and with a specific regimen for tuberculosis with isoniazid + pyridoxine, rifabutin, ethambutol and pyrazinamide for 2 months and, subsequently, with isoniazid + pyridoxine and rifabutin for 7 more months.
On follow-up, pericardial fluid culture was finally found to be positive for mycobacterium, further supporting the diagnosis.
A transthoracic echocardiogram was performed at 6 months, with the pericardial effusion resolved and no pericardial constriction.
The patient has now completed treatment for tuberculosis without complications and is afebrile and clinically well.
DIAGNOSIS Pericardial effusion due to Mycobacterium tuberculosis in a patient immunocompromised by renal transplantation.
Absence of signs of pericardial constriction at follow-up.
HISTORY, CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History
History Smoker of 3 cigarettes a day.
Severe mitral regurgitation secondary to chordal rupture pending surgery.

Pre-anaesthetic assessment performed, with last transthoracic echocardiography (TTE), transesophageal echocardiography (TTE) and pre-surgical coronary angiography without epicardial lesions the month prior to the episode.
Present illness 50-year-old male brought to hospital emergency department by SAMU after recovered cardiorespiratory arrest.

The patient presented at rest while watching television with an episode of loss of consciousness without previous symptoms, at which point his relative called 112 and started basic cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR).

On arrival of the SAMU, they observed cardiorespiratory arrest and began advanced CPR manoeuvres (laryngeal mask + mechanical ventilation), observing as the first rhythm ventricular fibrillation (VF), for which 5 shocks were administered, 450 mg of amiodarone and 3 mg of adrenaline, recovering sinus rhythm.
On arrival at the emergency department, a laryngeal mask was replaced by an endotracheal tube.
The patient was sedoanalgesiated and well adapted to mechanical ventilation, haemodynamically stable without vasopressor or inotropic drugs.
Physical examination Blood pressure (BP) 127/91 mmHg, heart rate (HR) 93 bpm, oxygen saturation 96% (IMV with FIO2 100%).
Cardiac auscultation: regular heart sounds, predominant systolic murmur in EIB.
Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur, crackles in the bases.
Abdomen: soft and depressible, no pain on palpation.
No oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis in the lower limbs.
Neurological: no sounds, no response to pain, medium photoreactive pupils.
COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram (ECG) on arrival at the critical care unit: sinus rhythm at 100 bpm, isolated ventricular extrasystoles, PR 160ms.
Narrow QRS with normal axis, without repolarisation alterations.
ECG during monitoring: sinus rhythm at 100 bpm, normal PR, frequent polytopic ventricular extrasystoles, narrow QRS with normal axis, signs of LVH, no significant repolarisation abnormalities.
Blood tests on arrival at the critical care unit: haemoglobin 17 g/dl, MCV 96.3 fl.
Na+ 137mmEq/l, K 4mmEq/l, Ur 36 mg/dl, creatinine 1.15 mg/dl, calcium 8.8 mg/dl, protein 6.6 g/dl, CRP 0.1 mg/dl, GPT 186 U/l, amylase 173 U/l.
Arterial blood gases on arrival (FiO2 50%): pH 7.16, pCO2 58 mmHg, pO2 113 mmHg, HCO3 20.7 mEq/l, Sat O2 98.8%, lactate 5.6 mmol/l.
Arterial blood gas one hour after arrival: pH 7.24, pCO2 50 mmHg, pO2 131 mmHg, HCO3 21.4 mEq/l, Sat O2 99.3%, lactate 3 mmol/l.
PCR SARS VOC 2 on arrival: negative.

Computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain: size of the ventricular system within the normal range, without significant dilatation of sulci, identifying no intracranial haematic collections, space-occupying lesions, fracture traces or alterations suggesting the presence of areas of acute ischaemia.
Pulmonary CT: bibasal condensation due to probable aspiration during orotracheal intubation (OTI).
Minimal undisplaced fractures of the 4th and 5th right anterior costal arches.
Chest X-ray: portable study with little inspiration, signs of vascular redistribution without showing infiltrates or pleural effusion.
TTE and TEE: mitral valve with eversion of the posterior leaflet at P2 (flail) due to chordal rupture.
Two divergent regurgitant jets of globally severe regurgitation (ORE by PISA 0.5 cm2, vena contracta 6-7 mm, regurgitant volume 96 ml).
Left ventricle (LV) of greatly increased diameters and volumes with mildly depressed systolic function (LVEF 45-50%).
Right ventricle with normal diameters and systolic function preserved in limits.
No signs of pulmonary hypertension (PAPS 30-35 mmHg).
CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was transferred to the coronary unit (UCO).
Cerebral and pulmonary CT was performed to rule out cerebrovascular accident (CVA), pulmonary thromboembolism (PTE) or acute aortic syndrome.
Given the CT findings, empirical antibiotic therapy was started.
A few hours later, he was extubated, with good clinical evolution and remained stable in haemodynamic and respiratory terms.
No neurological involvement was identified as a sequelae of the arrest.
The control chest X-ray showed disappearance of the alveolar infiltrates.
Ten days later, the cardiac surgery team operated to repair the mitral valve, placing a mitral ring and 4 neo-strings.
During surgery, extensive prolapse of P2, chordal rupture and cleft between P1-P2 were observed.
Postoperative TEE was performed and showed no residual mitral regurgitation (MR) after repair.

After the operation, he remained in the OCU, presenting several episodes of atrial fibrillation (AF) that led to haemodynamic instability and were controlled by electrical cardioversion (ECV) and intravenous amiodarone perfusion.
After reaching stability, a single-chamber implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) was implanted for secondary prevention.
He has continued to undergo check-ups at the clinic, remaining in NYHA functional class I and with no new arrhythmic events.
DIAGNOSIS Malignant mitral valve prolapse (complicated with recovered CRP).
Severe mitral insufficiency due to P2 prolapse due to chordal rupture, surgically repaired.
HISTORY, CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History
No cardiovascular risk factors or previous cardiological history.
Other antecedents: varicose veins in lower limbs.
Chronic treatment: oral contraceptive (levonorgestrel 0.1 mg/etinylestradiol 0.02 mg 1 tablet per day).
Present illness The patient presents with a self-limiting episode of precordial pain at rest.
It is attributed to musculoskeletal origin and treated with anti-inflammatory drugs.
At 22:15 hours the following day, she presented with a new episode of precordial pain, which did not subside with rest, together with general malaise.
Her husband called the emergency services.
At that moment, the patient suffered cardiorespiratory arrest (CRA) and her husband started basic cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR).
On arrival of the emergency services, a shockable rhythm was detected, which changed to sinus rhythm after 3 shocks at 200 joules.
Fifteen minutes of advanced CPR were recorded, with orotracheal intubation and invasive mechanical ventilation.
The outgoing electrocardiogram (ECG) showed right bundle branch block without clear ST-segment elevation, so the Infarction Code was not activated.
The patient was transferred to the emergency department of our centre.
Physical examination On arrival at the ED: temperature 36.7°C, blood pressure 90/73 mmHg, heart rate 92 bpm, respiratory rate 16 rpm, oxygen saturation 94%.
Sedoanalgesia, connected to invasive mechanical ventilation.
Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic heart sounds, tachycardic, no murmurs.
Carotid, radial and femoral pulses present.
COMPLEMENTARY TESTS CBC: haemoglobin 12.5 g/dl, MCV 95.9 fl, MCH 30.3 pg C, leukocytes 13,920/μl, platelets 398,000/μl.
Biochemistry: glucose 385 mg/dl, urea 27 mg/dl, creatinine 1.25 mg/dl, sodium 139 mmol/l, potassium 2.6 mmol/l, C-reactive protein 0.3 mg/dl.
Lipid profile: total cholesterol 165 mg/dl, LDL 94 mg/dl, HDL 33 mg/dl, triglycerides 194 mg/dl, HbA1C 5.4%.
Ultrasensitive troponin T (normal < 14 ng/l): serial on admission (on arrival, at 3 hours, at 24 hours, at 36 hours and at discharge): 204 --> 6,032--> 1,954 --> 2,003 --> 1,704 ng/l.
ECG: post arrest: sinus rhythm, negative T wave in V3-V5.
On admission to ICU: sinus rhythm, ST segment elevation from V2 to V4.
Angio-CT of pulmonary arteries: no evidence of pulmonary thromboembolism or deep vein thrombosis.
Cranial CT scan without contrast: no signs of acute intracranial pathology.
Echocardiogram in ICU: moderately affected LVEF (39%) with septoapical and apex akinesia, mid-septal and lateroapical hypokinesia.
Doubtful image at apical level (two chambers), which could correspond to thrombus.
Coronary angiography: right coronary artery without stenosis.
Left main coronary artery without stenosis.
Anterior descending artery (AD) with spiroid dissection from the proximal portion and occlusion in the middle segment, TIMI 0 flow.
Percutaneous coronary intervention to the LAD: intra-aortic balloon counterpulsation is implanted.

After verifying by IVUS the presence of coronary dissection with guidewire in the true lumen, three drug-eluting stents were implanted from the distal LAD to the ostial LAD with final TIMI 3 flow and without complications.
Echocardiogram with contrast: 13 x 8 mm mural thrombus in the apex of the left ventricle (LV).
CLINICAL EVOLUTION A 46-year-old woman was admitted after an out-of-hospital CRA resuscitated by a relative.
At the time no infarction code was activated by ECG without clear ST-segment elevation.
On arrival at the ED, other possible causes of CRA were ruled out (normal pulmonary CT angiography and cranial CT).
Initial emergency echocardioscopy showed no segmental contractility alterations.

She was transferred to the ICU, where she was sedated, perfused with low doses of noradrenaline, in sinus rhythm and without respiratory compromise; reactive to verbal stimuli, making coordinated movements with the upper limbs and with reactive pupils.

An echocardiogram was performed on admission to the ICU which showed ventricular dysfunction and segmental alterations in contractility in the territory of the LAD artery, so a repeat ECG was performed which showed an elevation of the anterior ST segment.

Emergent coronary angiography was performed, showing a spirodial dissection of the proximal LAD with occlusion at the level of the middle LAD and distal TIMI 0 flow, and three drug-eluting stents were implanted with good angiographic results, as well as intra-aortic balloon counterpulsation (IABP).
In the ICU, she had a favourable evolution that allowed the amine support and IABP to be withdrawn.
She was discharged to the hospital ward.
She remained in stable condition with amnesia of recent episodes as an identifiable immediate neurological sequela.

She remained with a tendency to arterial hypotension and sinus tachycardia during admission without clinical repercussions, which allowed the initiation of neurohormonal treatment with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE inhibitors) and beta-blockers.
Incidentally, in the initial echocardiogram with moderate LV dysfunction, an image suggestive of apical thrombus was observed, which was later confirmed with contrast echocardiography.
Electrocardiographically, the patient progressed to established myocardial necrosis with Q wave from V1 to V3.
At discharge, triple antithrombotic therapy was maintained with double antiplatelet therapy with acetylsalicylic acid, clopidogrel and acenocoumarol.
Acenocoumarol was withdrawn after 3 months of outpatient follow-up, after resolution of the thrombus.
DIAGNOSIS Out-of-hospital cardiorespiratory arrest in defibrillable rhythm, resuscitated.
Ischaemic heart disease, ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome (STEMI), Q-wave infarction secondary to spiroid dissection of the LAD with mid-segment occlusion.
Percutaneous treatment with implantation of three drug-eluting overlapping stents from distal LAD to ostial LAD.
Moderately affected LVEF in acute phase with mural thrombus in LV apex.
HISTORY, CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History

Tuberous sclerosis and epilepsy under follow-up by neurology and medical oncology (required treatment with everolimus which was suspended due to reduction of brain lesions, after which they remain stable in control brain MRI scans, the last one a month ago).
Giant subependymal astrocytomas and numerous cerebral cortical tuberosities.
Current treatment: lacosamide 150 mg/12 hours and topical sirolimus.

Present illness A 20-year-old male presented to the emergency department with recurrent vomiting of about 3 months' duration, initially postprandial and, subsequently, not clearly related to ingestion, together with diarrhoeal stools and pruritus.
No chest pain, no dyspnoea, no abdominal pain, no fever or other associated symptoms.
Cardiorespiratory auscultation: rhythmic tones at a good frequency, without murmurs or extratones.
Bladder murmur preserved with no extra sounds.
Abdomen: soft and depressible, not painful on palpation, with no signs of peritoneal irritation.
No masses or visceromegaly were palpable.
Lower extremities: no oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis.
COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Emergency venous blood gases: pH 7.44, sodium 135 mmol/l, potassium 3.4 mmol/l, haemoglobin 14.2 g/dl, lactic acid 2.3 mmol/l and bicarbonate 25.8 mmol/l.
Blood tests on admission: haemoglobin 13.6 g/dl, MCV 82.1 fl, leukocytes 4580/μl, neutrophils 2740/μl, lymphocytes 1330/μl and platelets 139000/μ Coagulation: INR 1.6 and TPAct 45%.

Biochemistry: glucose 88 mg/d, urea 45 mg/dl, creatinine 0.94 mg/dl, glomerular filtration rate 107 ml/min, sodium 138 mEq/l, potassium 3.5 mEq/l, chlorine 98 mEq/l, AST 76 U/l, ALT 122 U/l, GGT 44 U/l, alkaline phosphatase 58 U/l, TSH 3.78 mU/l.
Iron 23 μg/dl, ferritin 25.4 ng/ml, transferrin 241 mg/dl, TSI 7.51%.
Copper 1.70 mg/l (VN 0.65-1.65), ceruloplasmin 32 mg/dl (VN 20-60), α1-antitrypsin 177 mg/dl (VN 90-200).
Anti-mitochondrial, anti-smooth muscle, anti-LKM and anti-parietal cell antibodies negative.
Anti-transglutaminase antibodies IgA 0.60 (VN < 7) and IgA 282 mg/dl (VN 90-450).
Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy (EDA): normal oesophagus up to the cardia with small longitudinal fibrinous erosion of about 5 mm in length.
Stomach with good motility and distensibility with normal mucosa and without lesions except for slight petechiae in the fornix suggestive of secondary to nausea.
A sample was taken for urease.
Bulb and second duodenal portion without lesions.
Diagnosis: Los Angeles grade A erosive oesophagitis.
Control laboratory tests: haemoglobin 12.5 g/dl, MCV 81.3 fl, leukocytes 4920/μl, neutrophils 3090/μl, lymphocytes 1380/μl and platelets 203000/μ Coagulation: INR 1.8 and TPAct 39%.

Biochemistry: glucose 85 mg/dl, urea 45 mg/dl, creatinine 0.84 mg/dl, glomerular filtration rate 122 ml/min, sodium 137 mEq/l, potassium 3.6 mEq/l, chlorine 99 mEq/l, AST 79 U/l, ALT 111 U/l, GGT 39 U/l, alkaline phosphatase 58 U/l, total bilirubin 2.6 mg/dl.
Total cholesterol 91 mg/dl, HDL 15 mg/dl, LDL 62 mg/dl and triglycerides 70 mg/dl.
Total protein 5.6 g/dl, albumin 3.40 g/dl, prealbumin 7 mg/dl (VN 20-40), C-reactive protein 13.48 mg/l.
Serology: IgG positive for HSV and varicella zoster and negative for cytomegalovirus and Epstein-Baar virus.
Negative IgM for HSV, varicella zoster, cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Baar and hepatitis A.
Abdominal ultrasound: liver of normal size, borders and echogenicity, without focal lesions.
Gallbladder with double wall (ingested) without lithiasis.
Cava and suprahepatic ducts not dilated.
Patent portal of normal calibre (8.3 mm).
Diagnosis: small amount of fluid in the pelvis with no ultrasound evidence of chronic liver disease.
Renal cysts Thoracic-abdominal CT with contrast: Chest: thickening of the interlobular septa and bronchial walls associated with a faint ground-glass pattern in declined areas.
There is also cardiomegaly at the expense of the ventricles and rectification of the interventricular septum.
The trunk of the pulmonary artery is enlarged (up to 34 mm) and there is reflux of intravenous contrast into the superior venae cavae and suprahepatic veins.
Edema of the subcutaneous cellular tissue.
Abdomen: free fluid in pelvis, between loops, perihepatic and in both droplets.
Increased calibre of suprahepatic veins, suggestive of stasis.
Pancreas, spleen, adrenal glands and kidneys without appreciable findings.
Discrete edematous mural thickening in the cecum and right colon of non-specific appearance.
Intra-abdominal free fluid in moderate quantity.
Discrete oedematous thickening in the right cecum/colon, of non-specific appearance.
Blood tests on the cardiology ward: haemoglobin 14.6 g/dl, MCV 79.9 fl, leukocytes 4580/μl, neutrophils 6870/μl, lymphocytes 1520/μl and platelets 208000/μ Coagulation: INR 1.6 and TPAct 46%.

Biochemistry: glucose 82 mg/dl, urea 44 mg/dl, creatinine 0.86 mg/dl, glomerular filtration rate 119 ml/min, sodium 142 mEq/l, potassium 3.3 mEq/l, chlorine 95 mEq/l, AST 70U/l, ALT 112 U/l, GGT 49 U/l, LDH 407 U/l, total bilirubin 2.8 mg/dl, direct B.
Total cholesterol 115 mg/dl, HDL 17 mg/dl, LDL 81 mg/dl and triglycerides 82 mg/dl.
Total protein 6.6 g/dl, albumin 3.80 g/dl, iron 27 μg/dl, ferritin 35.5 ng/ml, transferrin 262 mg/dl, TSI 8.11%, folate 9.9 ng/ml and vitamin B12 717 pg/ml.
Electrocardiogram: sinus rhythm at about 65 bpm, signs of biauricular enlargement, long PR (BAV 1st degree), left axis, wide QRS with intraventricular conduction disturbances.
PA chest X-ray: increased cardiothoracic index, capillary redistribution pattern, signs of left atrial dilatation.
No alveolar infiltrates or images of pleural effusion.

Echocardiogram on admission: non-hypertrophic left ventricle (LV), severely dilated with severely depressed global systolic function due to global hypokinesia and asynchrony (IVS 8 mm, Dd 77 mm, TVD 218 ml, STV 149 ml, LVEF 31% by Simpson 4C, subjective LVEF 25%).
Biphasic left ventricular filling with diastolic dysfunction III and high filling pressures (E/A 2.5, E/e': 19).
Dilated right chambers with mild RV dysfunction (TAPSE 15 mm).
Mild tricuspid insufficiency (TI) allowing estimation of PSAP at 49 + PVC mmHg.
Conclusion: dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) with biventricular dysfunction.
No anomalies are visualised in coronary artery outflow.
Left coronary: left coronary trunk (LMCA) without lesions.
Normal LAD, without stenosis or lesions.
Marginal obtuse circumflex artery (Cx-OM) without lesions or calcium plaques, very thin.
Right coronary artery: own CD without calcium or significant stenosis.
Left ventricle very dilated along with the rest of the cavities with slow flow in the appendage (does not appear to be thrombus).
Enlarged pulmonary trunk (32 mm) without central pulmonary thromboembolism (PTE).
Persistent signs of pulmonary oedema (septal thickening, patchy ground glass, etc.
Conclusion: study without significant coronary lesions.
Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) without and with contrast (video 2): Left ventricle markedly dilated with severe dysfunction.
Right ventricle equally dilated with severe dysfunction (end-diastolic diameter 53 mm).
Enlargement of both atria, more accentuated left atrium (34 cm2, moderately dilated).
No areas of myocardial oedema on T2 sequence.
Ratio of non-compacted myocardium to compacted myocardium in the lateral aspect of the LV, fulfilling MRI criteria for non-compacted cardiomyopathy.
No myocardial perfusion defects are seen after contrast administration.
In late enhancement, a subendocardial area of late enhancement is seen at the septal level and to a lesser degree in the anterior aspect.
Conclusion: severe dilated cardiomyopathy with severe biventricular dysfunction.
No compaction in the lateral aspect (CNM criteria).
PA and lateral radiography after ICD-CRT implantation: increased cardiothoracic index, capillary redistribution pattern, signs of left atrial dilatation.
No alveolar infiltrates or images of pleural effusion.
ICD-CRT in left upper hemithorax with 3 normally positioned leads.
Blood tests prior to discharge: haemoglobin 12.5 g/dl, MCV 82.1 fl, leukocytes 6310/μl, neutrophils 3090/μl, lymphocytes 2550/μl and platelets 188000/μ Coagulation: INR 1.1 and TPAct 79%.

Biochemistry: glucose 85 mg/dl, urea 56 mg/dl, creatinine 1.02 mg/dl, glomerular filtration rate 97 ml/min, sodium 136 mEq/l, potassium 4.9 mEq/l, chlorine 97 mEq/l, AST 56 U/l, ALT 74 U/l, GGT 91 U/l, LDH 341 U/l, total bilirubin 1.5 mg/dl, direct B.
Total cholesterol 133 mg/dl, HDL 27 mg/dl, LDL 81 mg/dl and triglycerides 122 mg/dl.
Total protein 6 g/dl, albumin 3.60 g/dl, iron 40 μg/dl, ferritin 58.9 ng/ml, transferrin 262 mg/dl, TSI 12.02%.
Genetic study: after study of genes related to dilated cardiomyopathy, a variant of uncertain significance c.
(Arg1670His), in probable heterozygosis, has been observed in the LAMA4 gene.
Variants in this gene have been associated with dilated cardiomyopathy, a pathology with an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance.

Echocardiogram at one year follow-up (video 3): Severely dilated and dysfunctional left ventricle, due to very marked general hypokinesia and slight asynchrony; Dd 71 mm (2D), x Simpson calculations: VTD 246 ml, VTS 163 ml, EF 34%.
Biphasic left ventricular filling with E/A of 2.5, average E/e' 9.5.
Coil catheter in right chambers, right ventricle (RV) non-functioning with TAPSE of 19 mm and S' at 12 cm/s.
Very mild TR allowing estimation of PSAP at 35 mmHg + PVC.
Severe LV dysfunction with asynchrony unchanged with respect to previous ultrasound.
CLINICAL EVOLUTION During his evolution, the patient showed improvement in dyspnoea and oedematisation of the lower limbs, maintaining a good diuresis rate after adjustment of treatment.

Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging was requested, showing dilated cardiomyopathy with severe biventricular dysfunction, non-compaction on the lateral side and late anteroseptal subendocardial enhancement, which ruled out myocarditis as the cause.

However, in view of the finding of subendocardial late enhancement, angio-CT of the coronary arteries was requested to rule out ischaemic origin of the dysfunction in view of the possibility of a congenital coronary anomaly, but the study was normal.
Finally, a genetic study was requested to determine the aetiology, which was positive for DCM with variant of uncertain significance c.
(Arg1670His) in probable heterozygosis in the LAMA4 gene.

During follow-up, the patient showed good evolution without clinical signs of heart failure, but because the ejection fraction did not improve despite medical treatment, an implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) was implanted for primary prevention together with resynchronisation therapy (CRT) due to the presence of a wide QRS of 140 msec and asynchrony.
The ICD was implanted without incident, but a resynchronisation lead could not be implanted due to the impossibility of cannulating the coronary sinus.
The case was presented to the Heart Team to determine the best therapeutic option for failed CRT implantation, and the decision was made to implant a pacemaker with Hisian pacing.

The procedure was performed 6 months after diagnosis, in which the His zone was located with selective capture, but without QRS shortening, so the left branch was located, obtaining a narrower QRS (144 msec) but with R morphology in V1.

Currently, the patient is asymptomatic from the cardiac point of view, although with persistent left ventricular dysfunction and asynchrony in the echocardiographic control one year after diagnosis and after implantation of the pacemaker with physiological stimulation in the His bundle.

Therefore, this is a clinical case of a patient with diagnosed tuberous sclerosis associated with dilated cardiomyopathy whose aetiology has not been identified since the genetic study shows an inconclusive mutation.
The association between both entities is rare.
DIAGNOSIS Dilated cardiomyopathy in a patient with tuberous sclerosis.
Hisian physiological pacing pacemaker implantation in a patient with left ventricular dysfunction with asynchrony.
HISTORY, CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History
History 51-year-old male with the following personal history: No relevant family history of cardiological problems.
Cardiovascular risk factors: no arterial hypertension, diabetes or dyslipidaemia.
Current illness Consultation at the emergency department due to palpitations of several hours' duration, associated with a feeling of dizziness.
According to the patient, he had had palpitations on previous occasions, although they subsided in a self-limited manner with rest.
Given the persistence of the symptoms, she decided to go to hospital.
She had no other accompanying symptoms (no chest pain or dyspnoea).
Physical examination On physical examination he was haemodynamically stable, with a blood pressure of 110/55 mmHg and a heart rate of 217 bpm.
Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic heart sounds without murmurs.
Abdomen: soft, non-painful, no masses or megaliths.
Lower extremities: no oedema, no signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) with present and symmetrical pulses.
The electrocardiogram showed a regular wide QRS tachycardia at 217 bpm with atrioventricular dissociation and absence of Q wave in aVR, suggestive of ventricular tachycardia.
In view of the findings, the patient was transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) for continuous monitoring and surveillance.
COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Laboratory tests: blood count and coagulation within normal range.
Renal function and ions within normal parameters.
Electrocardiogram in tachycardia: regular tachycardia with wide QRS (LC 275 ms) with atrioventricular dissociation and absence of Q in aVR, suggestive of monomorphic VT.
Ventricular complex with superior electrical axis, positive in V1 (BRD morphology) and negative in I.
Basal electrocardiogram: sinus rhythm at 70 bpm.
Negative T waves in inferior face and lateral precordial.
Echocardiogram: left ventricle neither dilated nor hypertrophic with mild systolic dysfunction (LVEF 47%).
There was akinesia in the basal and middle segments of the inferolateral and lateral face.
The right ventricle shows preserved systolic function, with normal structure.
Absence of valvulopathies of interest, with normal morphology in the 4 valves.
Inferior vena cava not dilated with respiratory phasic changes.
Coronary catheterisation: coronary tree with normal distribution and development.
Cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR): dilated left ventricle with eccentric remodelling and moderate systolic dysfunction.
Left ventricular fatty infiltration and segmental contractility abnormalities.
Late subepicardial inferior and inferior subepicardial gadolinium enhancement at basal and midventricular levels.
Based on the enhancement observed, the findings are suggestive of arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy, and chronic myopericarditis cannot be ruled out.
CLINICAL EVOLUTION After admission to the ICU, the patient remained haemodynamically stable despite persistent tachycardia.
Echocardiography was performed, showing left ventricular dysfunction and akinesia in the basal and middle segments at the inferolateral and lateral levels.
The right ventricle maintained normal structure and preserved systolic function.

Treatment with amiodarone (intravenous infusion) was administered to control the ventricular tachycardia, achieving pharmacological cardioversion and recovering sinus rhythm a few hours after starting the infusion.
He remained in sinus rhythm for the next 48 hours, asymptomatic, and was transferred to the cardiology hospital ward to complete the aetiological study of the tachycardia.
Once on the hospital ward, a regular echocardiography was performed (in sinus rhythm), which confirmed mild systolic dysfunction and segmental disorders of left ventricular contractility.

In view of the findings, it was subsequently decided to perform a preferential coronary angiography to rule out coronary ischaemia as the cause of the symptoms, and a coronary tree with a normal distribution and no significant angiographic lesions was observed.
The patient remained in hospital for several days, remaining asymptomatic and in sinus rhythm.

Finally, cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) was performed, showing a striking subepicardial fatty infiltration in the left ventricle and late gadolinium enhancement (LGE) with subepicardial distribution.
These findings are suggestive of arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy of the left ventricle.
Subsequent genetic study confirmed the diagnosis, resulting in a pathogenic mutation for ACM in the FLNC gene (filamin C).

Once the case was presented and discussed in a clinical session, it was decided to implant an implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) for primary prevention of sudden death and to start treatment with beta-blockers.
Ablation of the arrhythmic substrate will be assessed in the follow-up in the event of persistent tachycardia or appropriate ICD discharges.
DIAGNOSIS Arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy of the left ventricle in structural phase.
HISTORY, CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History
Present illness She presented after a fall with rib trauma and fracture of several ribs.
Chest X-ray showed cardiomegaly and alteration of the aortic arch, so on-call cardiology was notified.
On questioning, the patient reported a previous episode of dizziness on exertion without loss of consciousness.
She denied dyspnoea, chest pain, haemoptysis or other associated symptoms.
She has two children born vaginally without complications.
Physical examination Heart rate 83 bpm, oxygen saturation 98% at baseline and 95% when walking 300 metres.
Cardiac auscultation: systolic murmur at the left sternal border.
Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur without added noise.
COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Blood tests: haemoglobin 13.8 g/dl, platelets 21 x1000/μl; NT-proBNP 230 pg/ml, troponin T hs: 5.5 ng/l.
Chest X-ray: fracture of the right posterior eighth arch and probable fracture of the seventh and ninth arch associated with right effusion, probable haemothorax given the rib fractures.
Cardiomegaly, alteration in the morphology of the superior mediastinum suggesting alteration in the arrangement of the aortic arch.
Likewise, given the cardiac morphology, pericardial effusion should be ruled out if there is no history of congenital heart disease.
No previous studies are available for comparison.
Complete right bundle branch block and evidence of right ventricular hypertrophy.
